Author: mithro_
Content:
* "It has never been easier to design your own silicon chip and now you can get 1,000 parts manufactured for just $7k USD."
* "It has never been easier to design your own silicon chip and now we will manufactured 1,000 parts for just $7k USD."
 * "It has never been easier to design your own silicon chip and now wafer.space provides low cost manufacturing."

Author: mithro_
Content: It has never been easier to design your own integrated circuit. Whatâ€™s missing is an affordable, straightforward path to real silicon that yields enough parts to build real products. For US$7,000, wafer.space delivers 1,000 raw dies so you can prototype, test, and ship.

Author: mithro_
Content: If anyone has time, I'd love your thoughts on the content @ https://docs.google.com/document/d/19QPzdnAufjkO7qodL7bISBagTFwljFhvuoXiNcOIue8/edit?tab=t.0

Author: mole99
Content:
One correction: GF180MCU (all caps) is the process, and gf180mcu is the open PDK

In the table maybe mention that Tiny Tapeout also offers other processes such as IHP SG13CMOS and SKY130?

How do you distribute full wafers if they contain proprietary designs? Or is that not a problem, since in the real world you could also simply decap a chip and reverse engineer it?

Otherwise, looks good! And ~1,000 bare dies are a nice unique selling point.

Author: mole99
Content: And one more thing: you mention top metal as if it were a separate layer, but in reality it is just a synonym for Metal5.

Author: anfroholic
Content:
## MOSbius

![](../images/features_update/mosbius_flow.png)

**MOSbius**, developed by **Professor Peter Kinget** and his students at **Columbia University**, is an innovative educational platform that helps students and designers explore **MOS circuit topologies** typically found on silicon and now accessible on a breadboard.

The goal of MOSbius is to give learners hands-on experience with **transistor-level design**, including circuit debugging, measurement, and the full â€œchip bring-upâ€ process. The platform allows users to compare calculations, simulations, and real measurements using provided **LTspice models**, bridging the gap between theory and silicon.

[![](../images/features_update/mosbius_interview.png)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=abu3u6UX6wE)
*MOSbius â€“ A Field Programmable Transistor Array for Chip Designers*
*Interview with Peter Kinget*

Their current board design requires numerous passive components due to varying pin voltage levels, and each packaged chip can cost upwards of **$50**. With their new design on the **Wafer.Space** platform, all pins will be **3.3 V tolerant**, dramatically simplifying their demo board and lowering overall complexity.

By leveraging **Wafer.Spaceâ€™s low-cost fabrication process**, the MOSbius team is able to minimize production expenses and make their chips available to the **educational community at a nominal cost** â€” expanding access to hands-on silicon learning for students and researchers worldwide.

Weâ€™re thrilled to have MOSbius as part of this shuttle run and proud to support a project that aligns so perfectly with Wafer.Spaceâ€™s mission!

Learn more about the project at [**mosbius.org**](https://mosbius.org/0_front_matter/intro.html).

Author: anfroholic
Content:
### Their Own COB Format

Given the unique requirements of the MOSbius project, the team is designing their own version of a **Chip-on-Board (COB)** package based on the Wafer.Space standard padframe.

Their application prioritizes **a high number of I/O connections** over power and ground pads, allowing for the maximum number of accessible signals from their transistor array.

**Peterâ€™s student, @xianglin_pui**, has taken the lead on this effort and developed derivative designs that extend the Wafer.Space COB standard for MOSbiusâ€™s specialized needs.
